unnormalised: Hey everyone, someone asked me about taking out a loan, specifically a personal loan, so thought I’d share my 2 cents. I took a personal loan of Rs. 2,00,000 last year from HDFC Bank to prepone my sister's wedding and honestly, the process wasn't as scary as I initially thought. I did a lot of research beforehand though.
normalised: Hey everyone, someone asked me about taking out a loan, specifically a personal loan, so thought I'd share my two cents. I took a personal loan of rupee two hundred thousand last year from H-D-F-C Bank to prepone my sister's wedding and honestly, the process wasn't as scary as I initially thought. I did a lot of research beforehand though.

unnormalised: First things first, shop around! Don't just jump at the first offer you see from SBI or ICICI Bank. Websites like BankBazaar and Paisabazaar let you compare interest rates and processing fees from various lenders. I found a difference of almost 0.5% in interest rates, which adds up when you’re talking about a loan of 2 lakh rupees or more. Also, watch out for hidden charges! These guys are smart.
normalised: First things first, shop around! Don't just jump at the first offer you see from S-B-I or I-C-I-C-I Bank. Websites like BankBazaar and Paisabazaar let you compare interest rates and processing fees from various lenders. I found a difference of almost zero point five percent in interest rates, which adds up when you're talking about a loan of two lakh rupees or more. Also, watch out for hidden charges! These guys are smart.

unnormalised: Next, figure out how much you actually need. Don't be tempted to borrow more just because you can. A higher loan amount means higher EMIs (Equated Monthly Installments), and that’s extra stress on your monthly budget. I needed exactly Rs. 2,00,000, so that's what I applied for. Remember, a loan tenure that stretches out too long at 5 yrs can lead to paying much more interest overall, even if the monthly payments seem manageable.
normalised: Next, figure out how much you actually need. Don't be tempted to borrow more just because you can. A higher loan amount means higher E-M-I-s (Equated Monthly Installments), and that's extra stress on your monthly budget. I needed exactly rupee two hundred thousand, so that's what I applied for. Remember, a loan tenure that stretches out too long at five years can lead to paying much more interest overall, even if the monthly payments seem manageable.

unnormalised: Make sure you have all your documents in order. Banks usually ask for your Aadhaar card, PAN card, salary slips for the last 3 months, and bank statements for the last 6 months. Keep photocopies ready because you will definitely need them. You can apply online, but I preferred going to the branch just to get everything clarified upfront. The RM (Relationship Manager) was actually quite helpful.
normalised: Make sure you have all your documents in order. Banks usually ask for your Aadhaar card, P-A-N card, salary slips for the last three months, and bank statements for the last six months. Keep photocopies ready because you will definitely need them. You can apply online, but I preferred going to the branch just to get everything clarified upfront. The R-M (Relationship Manager) was actually quite helpful.

unnormalised: Finally, pay your EMIs on time! Late payments can seriously dent your credit score (CIBIL score), which will make it harder to get loans in the future. I set up auto-debit from my account so I never miss a payment. It's been almost a year now, and I’ve paid off about 1/3 of the loan. Good luck, and think carefully before you commit to a loan!
